block.p: Bouquets of fresh litchis, nubbly rose-red fruits hanging like little lanterns from their stems, now decorate produce stands in Chinatown.
Puncture the crisp shell and inhale the heady fragrance of the pearly, translucent fruit. The sweet, juicy flesh comes away easily.
Bouquets of fresh litchis, nubbly rose-red fruits hanging like little lanterns from their stems, now decorate produce stands in Chinatown.
Puncture the crisp shell and inhale the heady fragrance of the pearly, translucent fruit. The sweet, juicy flesh comes away easily.

Cut litchis in half to remove the pit, and add them to fruit salads or a duck breast saute or puree them for a sorbet. Unpeeled and on the stem, they will keep for a couple of weeks in the refrigerator.

In Chinatown, the bunches are $8 at Ken Hing, 247 Grand Street (Chrystie Street). They are also sold loose, at $7.99 a pound, at Manhattan Fruit Exchange in the Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), and at $6.99 a pound at Gourmet Garage stores.
